prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for taking my 3yo out to do something fun whilst my partner is at work?
I will try and keep this short . 

Almost every weekend when I say lets take our kid out to the play centre or a farm ect I get one of maybe 3  excuses every time without fail . Either "I dont want to go out / I just wanna sit and play on the computer. " " ive been at work im tired I don't wanna go out / drive " or " I don't wanna spend the money on x, y ,z" ( we have money so its not like thats a real problem )   

Today a friend asked me if i wanted to go with her with the kids to the farm near us tomorrow and I said yes . I figured since we hadn't taken little one anywhere fun for a few weeks it would be nice . 

So I mentioned it to my partner and he goes off on one about how its not fair as he is at work and he would like to go blah blah . I said so I cant take her anywhere when you're at work ? Pointed out that I asked to go not a week or two earlier and was told no its too expencive and  I dont want to go out I'm tired. ( its £7 each ). 

So now he wants me to cancle with my friend so he can go another day . I said we can go whenever you want . But apparently thats not an option either . 

Its a childrens petting zoo ffs its not like im going to see a movie wothout him. 
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The user is asking whether the person who wrote the AITA (Am I the Asshole) post is in the wrong for taking their 3-year-old to a fun activity while their partner is at work.

First, I need to look at the details given. The parent mentions that almost every weekend they suggest taking the child to a play center or farm, but the partner gives excuses like not wanting to go, being tired, or not wanting to spend money. The parent points out they have money, so it's not a financial issue. This time, the parent agreed to go with a friend to the farm, which the partner found out and got upset because he's at work and wants to go. The parent had previously tried to go out but was refused for similar reasons. Now the partner wants to cancel so he can go later, but the parent is saying "we can go whenever you want."

The key points here are about shared responsibilities in parenting and communication. The parent is taking initiative to spend quality time with the child when the other partner is unavailable. The partner seems to be inconsistent because he previously didn't want to go out, possibly due to personal reasons (tiredness, not interested) and now is upset when the other parent does it. The cost is also mentioned as £7 each, which isn't a significant expense, so the initial excuses about money don't hold up.

In terms of fairness, the parent is prioritizing the child's needs for social interaction and fun, which is important for a 3-year-old. The partner's reaction seems more about being left out rather than the child's well-being. The parent isn't excluding the partner entirely; they're just taking action when the partner isn't available. The partner's previous excuses suggest he's not actively participating in those activities, so the parent making the choice to go with a friend is reasonable.

There's also the aspect of communication. The parent informed the partner about the plans, and the partner was upset, but the parent had already given similar excuses in the past. The parent is standing their ground by saying they can go whenever the partner wants, which implies willingness to accommodate in the future.

So, considering all these factors, the parent isn't in the wrong. The partner's reaction is more about his own feelings rather than the child's best interest. The parent is fulfilling their role by providing the child with enjoyable experiences when the other parent is unavailable and uninterested.
